instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Hello there ! 

I have a 3437-B from a MBA 2013. At the beginning I had no light on charger and no fan spin, no more historic. I found corrosion on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> supply, I replaced the bad components and still no light on charger. I tried reflow SMC without success, and I finally had a light on charger after replacing the SMC with a working one. Now I have light on charger but still no fan spin. I finally found out something that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present on the board but it's shorted...

I don't know if it's shorted since the beginning but I tried to remove the SMC, also <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and every component attach to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and I still have the short. I also looked for broken traces and bad resistances value, found nothing. I finally throw it in the ultrasonic cleaner but still shorted.

It's a dead board to me but if you have any advice I would be glad to hear it :) Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Which is the exact ohm value of that short?
Not a good idea to remove ALL components from <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
I hope you didn't power on the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>!!!

Lift L7560 one side and see where the short remains...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: I never plugged the board since I removed SMC and <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. The short is 22ohms. When I lift L7560 the short is on PIN 2 and when <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> lift up the short is only on PIN17, it looks like the short is on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_R</SIGNAL>. When I remove components I put them back in place after I checked the short still there, i do it page by page, don't know if it is a good methodology.... Every caps and resistors on page 54 are fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
22 ohm is a bit high to heat something.
But you can try injecting voltage there, no more than 4V.
You may need to give it time; IR camera may help.
Can also have luck and maybe the culprit chip enter in thermal avalanche and heats faster.
Remove CPU heatsink first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Actually <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is shorted but present, so could it heat with the MagSafe only ? I don't have any lab supply yet and I tried with the MagSafe and an IR camera, the only hot point is under PCH (or the other side of the board I don't know). CPU heatsink was already removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
You have other volatges present too; that dowsn't help to locate one chip from <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> goes directly to PCH and its big size distributes the heat on entire CPU.
So probably is the culprit...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Alright so your guess is reballing CPU ? Maybe dead CPU ? No way that I am doing a reballing CPU for a 3437-B, neither a CPU swap...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Reballing why, like a masage at a wood foot???
Of course you can try; nothing to lose, if the board is trash anyway.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: haha exactly like a massage at a wood foot ! I'l try it and let you know at least if the short was coming from there. I would be very sad to remove the CPU and still have the short...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Hi, so to let you know the end of this, I removed the CPU properly and the short is gone, so the problem was the CPU or the connexions to the CPU. I know it's a pain in the ass to reattach a CPU to a motherboard but I have time to spend on it and it worth the try as I have some junk <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B. Do you know where I could find a stencil to reball a CPU for this board ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Puff, you should search on Aliexpress, or eBay.
There must be some chinese to sell it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message: Ok i find a stencil as the reference SR16Q. It will arrive here in two weeks or so, I'll let you know if the reparation is a succes or a disaster :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted
threads.message:
Original CPU shorted, that is the disaster.
Even if repair will not be successfull, you will get some experience; soldering such type of BGA...
